comment: Today's weather is the kind that makes you want to get home early and put on a pot of tea.
I took this recipe from Tasty Ever After and simplified it a bit. Received many compliments!
recipe: Peel and chop the onion and garlic. Place both in the Instant Pot with your olive oil and turn on the Saute function. Saute the onion and garlic until soft. Add all of the chicken, 1/2 cup of the barbecue sauce, and all of the apple cider vinegar. Lock the lid, select the Poultry setting, and set the timer for 20 minutes. When the cycle is done, do a quick release, open the lid, and shred the chicken. There will be a lot of liquid at this point, do not worry. Leave the lid off and turn on the Saute function. Add the remaining 1/2 cup of barbecue sauce and mix for a few minutes as the chicken continues to thread. Spoon chicken onto medium sized, toasted buns. Serves 8.

comment: Here's the create-elm-app Node tool I used to create the application boilerplate.
Here's my first attempt at using Elm to parse truffles. Loading feed.json as a static asset for now
About to start an Elm app for Truffles. Let's see how this goes!
Finished rewatching All Stars Season 2 with friends of ours. We also watched the Reunited episode, which we'd skipped before. So much respect for Alyssa Edwards. Katya is still my favorite.

Considering a switch to Elm for the truffle reader. Vue.js seems to be a nice balance between flexibility and whatever adjectives you'd like to use to describe Angular, but I think Elm might actually get me there faster (even though I'm still learning it.)
Andrew and I have been enjoing this series. It's produced by Michael Schur (Parks and Recreation, Brooklyn 99), so if you like his stuff, give it a try.

Currently burning an apple cinnamon scented candle we picked up in Michigan! Don't tell my mother-in-law, but we also accidentally picked up one of her plastic containers to transport cider doughnuts.

Four years ago today, I came out of the closet. I never thought I'd be talking about being married to my husband four years later, but here I am. Here's the link to the original post I made when I came out.

Having one of those evenings where I'm finding myself doing more development tool shopping than actual coding. I think this article though finally gets me a bit closer to using Vue.js the way I want it to behave.
I wonder what this analogy would look like if it were updated for today?
I finally mailed some poop today. I don't think we have heartworms to worry about, but it doesn't hurt to check.
If I had the time and money, I'd start a Christian LGBTQIA coffeeshop/bar in Austin. Everyone welcome!

I've sometimes said the thing that gets you hooked on programming is the moment you start getting more work out of a piece of code than what you put into it. However, a thought occurred to me today: instead of talking about the work I'm getting out of the code, what if I talked about the joy I'm getting out of it? The Truffle project is something I do in my spare time for no money. I don't believe I'll ever get rich off it, but there's certainly a lot of opportunity for joy. Part of what brings me joy is running the script that generates a "blank" truffle I can start filling. I'm making a point to start every session I work on Truffle with that joy!
Just got back from a puppy party. Our dog is worn out!
Giving Vue.js a whirl for rendering truffles. Liking it so far, but will want to refine the output to my needs.
About to head out to meet other homeschooled/unschooled alumni for a meetup!
Got the coordinates wrong, these are the correct ones!

As I walked up today, I noticed a bunch of people with small plastic bowls. When I went inside, there was a woman behind a table selling Thai food. She said her mother makes the food, it's different every week, and they bring it to this location on Wednesdays. It looks like they also have it on Thursdays and Fridays at other locations too.
These couple of verses are the kind where while they're part of a larger passage, you find yourself saying 'Oof, that's really something to think about.'
I liked the flavor, but it needed a little bit of salt and a few red pepper flakes to make it right.
Finally fixed the display of truffle.jlleblanc.com for mobile. Thanks StackOverflow and Bootstrap!
Haven't eaten this yet, but it's a bit more Instant Pot experimentation.
ingredients: Three medium carrots, chopped into rounds
Half of a bunch of kale, chopped (three stalks)
recipe: Place the carrots, onions, kale, tomato sauce, and a few shakes of Italian seaoning in the pot. Add olive oil to a skillet and turn the heat to high. Fry up the garlic and fennel seed in the skillet for about 30 seconds. Brown the turkey in the skillet until it's cooked through. Close the pot and set it to high pressure for 10 minutes. Do a quick release and serve.

comment: Showing Andrew how to add another truffle to the feed.

When I listened to this episode of Freakonomics, the description of the Esperanto community reminded me of the Joomla! project. I don't think I would be prepared to hand over my car keys to just anyone claiming to be from the Joomla! community. However, that feeling like you're coming home even when you're visiting a city you've never been to rings true.
Here's a list of the beers (and one cider) we bought and shared.
beers: Oasis Texas Brewing Company - Slow Ride Pale Ale

comment: Got ready for a party on the lake. Always love shopping here!
Today I played a little Instant Pot routlette. Here's what I made.
ingredients: Half of a rotisserie chicken, deboned and defatted
Approximately 3 cups of chopped napa cabbage
Half a cup of red onion
Approximately a tablespoon of fish sauce
Approximately a tablespoon of soy sauce
Half a cup of plain water
recipe: Peel and slice the sweet potatoes. Peel and mince the ginger. Chop the cabbage into bite-size strips. Place all of the ingredients in the Instant Pot for 10 minutes on high pressure, then use the quick release. Serve.

comment: This one never gets old!
